newsitem.title: USA: Lucid back on earth as shuttle lands.
newsitem.headline: Lucid back on earth as shuttle lands.

text.p: After 188 days in orbit, NASA's space endurance champion Shannon Lucid returned to earth on Thursday aboard shuttle Atlantis.

The $2 billion reusable spaceship touched down at Florida's Kennedy Space Center at 8:13 a.m. EDT (1213 GMT), bringing to an end Lucid's record-breaking, six-month mission to Russia's space station Mir.
On its 10-day flight, Atlantis collected Lucid from the Russian space station Mir where she had spent six months in orbit, longer than any other American and a record for a woman of any nationality.

The 53-year-old mother of three rode home aboard Atlantis in a reclining seat to cushion her body against the tug of gravity. After six months in weightlessness, the space agency's doctors expected her to feel weak and woozy.
Blaha, a 54-year-old former Vietnam veteran, replaced her aboard Mir where he is due to spend four months.
